column4: Post

From what I have learned, I define culture as the beliefs and norms of a specific group which are passed down to later generations. This is a definition that I learned from multicultural education where we focused on the idea that our culture is a key factor in how we construct knowledge. As far as eLearning, I define it as a type of learning that is done online and very different from traditional classrooms because there is typically no face-to-face interaction and learning is done remotely without having to be in a physical classroom.

I like to think of eLearning as a way to bring different cultures together and this is how they are related. This means that people from different parts of the state, or the world for that matter, are learning with and about each other. This is one of the wonderful aspects of eLearning because it gives minority groups an opportunity to share their experiences with a wider audience than a traditional classroom would. For example, many students are uncomfortable sharing in face-to-face classroom discussions. In an online environment, you have to share your ideas and this is where many quiet students flourish because they are able to express themselves better than in a traditional classroom. Another way culture and eLearning are related is they provide opportunities to exchange ideas which are later passed on to other groups. I see this all the time in the classroom discussions we have in on our online courses. I have learned so much from my peers' responses and the experiences they've shared and have made me reflect on my own views and consider new perspectives.

This is a definition that I learned from multicultural education where we focused on the idea that our culture is a key factor in how we construct knowledge. As far as eLearning, I define it as a type of learning that is done online and very different from traditional classrooms because there is typically no face-to-face interaction and learning is done remotely without having to be in a physical classroom.
I like to think of eLearning as a way to bring different cultures together and this is how they are related. This means that people from different parts of the state, or the world for that matter, are learning with and about each other. This is one of the wonderful aspects of eLearning because it gives minority groups an opportunity to share their experiences with a wider audience than a traditional classroom would. For example, many students are uncomfortable sharing in face-to-face classroom discussions. In an online environment, you have to share your ideas and this is where many quiet students flourish because they are able to express themselves better than in a traditional classroom. Another way culture and eLearning are related is they provide opportunities to exchange ideas which are later passed on to other groups. I see this all the time in the classroom discussions we have in on our online courses. I have learned so much from my peers' responses and the experiences they've shared and have made me reflect on my own views and consider new perspectives.

I agree Mark that there is often a negative connotation around eLearning. My daughter was a high school junior when her school abruptly transitioned to online learning. She hated it! As a result , she did pretty poorly. Those first few months of self-isolating was really hard on her (as it was for all of us, of course). But now, five months later, this has become the new norm. And while she is only a week into her senior year with only eLearning, she is loving it. She likes that the structure gives her time to one-on-one with her teachers and there is plenty of time in the day to do assignments. It's interesting to see the change.

I agree Mark that there is often a negative connotation around eLearning. My daughter was a high school junior when her school abruptly transitioned to online learning. She hated it! As a result , she did pretty poorly. Those first few months of self-isolating was really hard on her (as it was for all of us, of course). But now, five months later, this has become the new norm. And while she is only a week into her senior year with only eLearning, she is loving it. She likes that the structure gives her time to one-on-one with her teachers and there is plenty of time in the day to do assignments. It's interesting to see the change.

Mark- It's interesting how you brought up the fact that online degree programs were originally frowned upon because this is something I was thinking about too. They were often seen as not as good of a program and/or taking the easy route, but now that is not the case. Online learning is now seen as the norm for working and busy professionals. Now with Covid, I really feel like society has really adapted to eLearning especially k-12 grade students.

Mark, My organization uses eLearning in much the same way.  The real irony of it is that, if a student performs poorly on the test at the end, they often have to schedule a meeting with an instructor to go over the material.  That doesn't seem to be the best use of eLearning potential to me. LOL!
I have seen it used well in some cases.  About 12 years ago, I had to take a significant amount of on-line training with FEMA.  Their courses were pretty good - not awesome.  There was very little interaction, though.

Hi Peter,  All of the eLearning I've taken has been mandatory. There's something about words like compliance that create an adverse reaction to learning. I think that we've assimilated those ideas to eLearning because of our exposure to the type of content. For APS we had annual compliance training and now I have quarterly to follow the fiscal schedule. What gets me is the outdated videos and animations. Thanks for sharing.

I agree that there are negative perceptions of eLearning Mark, and I wonder if many times it is stemming from a lack of familiarity or a resistance to alternative ways of learning. When the pandemic left the Children's Campus with no choice but to close while we all figured out safety measures and gained understanding of what was happening, we decided to embark on remote learning with toddlers and preschoolers. At first parents and teachers were very unsure how to implement the curriculum and how the children would benefit. This told me that we were focused only on the actual presence of the adults caring for children and not the relationship and learning that takes place in the classroom each day. Within a couple of weeks we had groups of preschoolers using zoom and marco polo to have cirlce time, group activities, child led show and tell, and other learning and opportunities to maintain relationships. Now that we are reopen many of the groups are still using these formats and incorporating them into their current curriculum. It has been an amazing journey to witness!

That's so encouraging to hear, Lisa. Sounds like it would be worthwhile to document this whole process carefully since it's a testament to our versatility when the community is on board with new concepts. Sounds like a great action response on the part of Children's Campus.

Thank you Eva, and that is a great idea. It has been an interesting balance to create programming that supported the children while at home, continued to build on their development, work with parents to support this at home and plan for a safe return. We are now back on campus in a mixed model method as the parents are not allowed in the campus or in classrooms and therefore the entire parent component is still happening remotely, but the children's learning is happening in the traditional way (but with all new safety protocols of course), so as you mentioned we continue to be versatile and responsive to the demands of both the care and education of the children and the health and safety of us all!
Good luck! Flexibility is certainly key now and moving forward. I hope the classes are helpful in that process. Certainly lots to think about!

We are definitely living in a time of rapid change. How have your children adjusting to online/remote learning?
I've away from the classroom for close to two years. My students were always excited to learn new tools and to use tech tools. I know that students are open to new ideas and ways of learning. I hope that they are doing well. Teachers are also very resilient and I can't wait to see how our education system and society evolves from this pandemic.

Hello Mark, The children adjusted well during that time and we supported parents in helping to implement and extend some of what we were working on with the children. The children are back on campus in a regular classroom setting and it was great to see that the months away did not impact the relationships they have with their teachers and peers. No doubt the continued online contact had a lot to do with that!
I'm so glad to hear the update! I'm glad to hear things are going great.

Melissa- Glad to meet you. Your point about eLearning being more community-focused is interesting. I feel that both eLearning and in person instruction have their benefits among the community; however with digital instruction it can feel that you are just talking or producing content for a computer screen instead of having a sense of a "classroom family".  Another drawback to eLearning involves grading, whereas a traditional teacher might give assistance with extra points or special content for a student that is struggling, in many eLearning systems the material is uniform with limited customization for each student. I feel that eLearning is good on a hybrid or alternative schedule (as many schools are doing this fall) and has the benefit of being able to learn at unlimited places and/or times; however I don't think it will fully replace in person learning due to the rigidness of many eLearning system processes and procedures.

Hi Wyatt, You brought excellent points regarding some of the drawbacks that are found in eLearning. The human element is what has made traditional face-to-face learning stand the test of time. People like physical assistance and face-to-face communication and seeing someone else's body language. Virtual learning can't replace that and that is why it such a huge issue for elementary teachers. Kids need compassion and support from a human being than from a person they see on a computer screen. In today's classrooms, it is so sad to see that many kids do not have a supportive adult in their lives and teachers are the first to provide that to some children. Thank you for your insight, it really made me reflect on my personal teaching experience.

I agree Wyatt about the virtual wall that we face in eLearning. Even in a best case scenario, with optimum video and audio, I feel like you can't read a person's body language and personality--things that I think we subconsciously use in person to learn.

Wyatt- your point about a lack of "classroom family" stuck out to me because this is something I am currently facing with my high school students right now during teaching online because of Covid. Since I have yet to meet my students in person, it has been more difficult to build genuine relationships with my students on an individual basis. I have also noticed that the students aren't building relationships with eachother like they normally do when we are face to face. Another draw back I have noticed is the eLearning feels like the curriculum is less individualized than when teaching in person because when teaching online everyone is given the same assignment with the same requirements. I agree with you about  eLearning being great because students all over are able to access their classes any time and any where.

Faith, Do you think that part of community building has to do with framing it differently? I look at how assiduously my kids research products they buy online: that review process indicates to me a level of interactive learning and community building which may not be overt but actually indicates that we can create a hive mind in many different situations. Would it be possible to create a thread that helps students find common interests and get comfortable sharing with one another?

Hi Melissa, you brought up such a good point that I did not even consider- eLearning brings a vast array of cutlures together which makes it an important tool for learning about each other and gaining tolerance.

Hi Melissa, I absolutely agree with you! ELearning is an opportunity to even the playing field for individuals who are challenged in traditional classroom settings even as diverse cultural content can be shared. 
I appreciate hearing how this also plays out in your personal experience with the program. I look forward to this opportunity to share in these experiences.

Hi Tanya, At one point in my college journey, I was told the same thing by an advisor and it was so discouraging. I couldn't afford to quit my job and go to school, but somehow I was able to complete my elementary education degree. Now, they offer all these online courses and ways to get your degree online that were not available to me and this was just like 2 years ago! I am glad that your niece and her friends have been able to continue their education and have the accommodations they need to be successful. It's sad that a pandemic finally shook universities to make changes if they wanted to retain students. I hope this continues even after we are past this mess. I am glad that you are starting to warm up to eLearning, it is definitely a challenge for people who are used to traditional learning including instructors! Ultimately, everyone needs to be open to change and it's just crazy that it has taken this long for everyone to learn more about eLearning and work on how to make it better.

Tanya, I am so sorry to hear that your niece's friends were told they could not be accommodated.  Unfortunately, it took a world-wide crisis for organizations to realize that for some things, there is a different, more inclusive way to do things.  I, too, did not like online classes when I first tried them about fifteen years ago.  However, I chalk that up to growing pains - both for programs and students.Melissa, I was telling a friend of mine when I finally graduated, that I could not have done it with the evolution of online programs.  It took me 28 years to get my degree.  Much of that had to do with the fact I could never leave work on time and missed a lot of classes.  Like you, I could not afford to quit my job.  I plan on getting this degree in two years.  Part of that has to do with the fact I would only consider a master's degree that was 100% online despite me literally living up the street from a university.  Although it is probably more work, it beats having to juggle tight work and school schedules, fight traffic, fight parking, only to listen to someone lecture for three hours while starving and wondering if your dogs can hold their bladders until you can get home to let them out.

Hi Michelle, Yes, eLearning has opened the opportunity for full-time workers to make their dreams of obtaining a degree with a reputable university a reality! It was not long ago where the idea of online courses was an option, but now universities have to be flexible if they want to stay open and generate revenue. We have been very fortunate that we have the ability to learn in the comfort of our home, I feel that is the best accommodation for a variety of learners!

Hi Melissa! Good to be in class together again! I like your idea that eLearning can be a way to bring diverse cultures together. I find your analysis of quiet students' behavior in the online learning environment to be quite accurate according to the way I am seeing my students behave in our Google classroom.

Hey Becky!  I was so happy to see that you were in this class! :)  I am glad that we have the same views in regards to eLearning. I hope this course will prepare you to lead teachers as they continue to get acquainted with eLearning and remembering the importance of differentiation, Universal Design of Learning, and equity. I feel like as teachers these are things we are familiarized with, but it is so easy to forget about this as we adjust to virtual classrooms.

Culture is a sum total of one's identity within an ethnic group. Culture includes food, art, traditions, celebrations, rituals, religion, beliefs, language (verbal and non-verbal). and dress. Culture is learned and transferred from one generation to another via oral traditions, interactions, and intentional teaching.  
eLearning is characterized as learning that is not in an in-person/classroom setting, using technology. This may require hardware and the use and knowledge of technology. eLearning is convenient for some and is accessible to learners in various geographic locations. eLearning is characterized as having pre-recorded learning modules that are interactive and immersive. Some eLearning modules include videos, multiple-choice assessments, and pre-recorded content. 
The connection between eLearning and culture may be that both have a set of rules, a distinct language, and practices.

Hi Mark, I think you made an excellent point that eLearning is somewhat of a novelty in many companies when it comes to training and development and usually used to meet the compliance rules of the organization. I believe that with our current situation, eLearning is at it's prime as it's not only a resource used by higher education and organizations, but they are being used at a pre-school and elementary education level. For example, our primary educators are using LMS systems to teach and I know that many want little to do with eLearning because they are used to traditional learning. I think people are afraid of eLearning because it's a learning curve, but there are so many benefits to eLearning that are overlooked and as we start collaborating this semester, we will see how accessible it is to many different groups. 
In regards to your definition of culture and eLearning, I agree with both of your definitions because they accurately define both terms. As far as eLearning and culture having the same set of rules, can you elaborate a bit more? Are you talking about  how eLearning has norms such as netiquette and creating a social presence which are no different than the cultural norms we have to follow such as obeying traffic signs?

Hi Laura, Thinking about how eLearning and culture are alike was a bit challenging. I have a biased view of eLearning as a former classroom teacher and now a facilitator for virtual learning. I acknowledge that eLearning is an effective means of learning with the potential of reaching a global audience and I realize that there are impediments to learning that may be influenced by outside factors which include access to technology, social class, and computer literacy. Culture has a set of implicit rules which are known or recognized by the members of a group. For example, in the Arabic culture children do not make eye contact with adults because it is a form of disrespect, or in Japan people don't speak out of turn or interrupt conversations to interject.  
eLearning has it's set of explicit rules which are accepted by all who opt to use the tool for learning. The rules are clear and expectations are set; the example you shared of obeying traffic lights. Another example of an explicit rule for eLearning is this class; we have clear instructions as to how we should be conducting discussions within this course with our peers. G32:H32Thank you for helping me think about this topic a bit more.

I decided to see what Google said about Culture: 
Culture is the characteristics and knowledge of a particular group of people, encompassing language, religion, cuisine, social habits, music and arts. ... The word "culture" derives from a French term, which in turn derives from the Latin "colere," which means to tend to the earth and grow, or cultivation and nurture.
This definition seems similar to what you guys have already suggested- "beliefs and norms of a specific group" or the collective identity of a group. Reading about the Latin origin made me think of the Native American teaching about the two conflicting wolves that develop inside of you.  Which one will dominate/ win the conflict?  The one that you feed.  Our collective culture will be dominated by the behavior and thoughts that we continue to express.  We will pass certain overt and covert ideas from generation to generation.  Other ideas fade out.

Hello, Dixie.  I like the reading excerpts you introduced.  As far as feeding culture, in eLearning, we should feed good habits to create a positive culture of learning.
Hello, Mark.  I know how you feel.  At jobs, I dreaded eLearning as it was really only used for compliance.  Although the EEO and Title IX policies have a lot of very important information, they were presented dryly, and the entire organization could tell that the developers were only doing it to check a box; so, when I was asked to create online training modules for finance training, I did not want to do this.  However, after COVID-19 forced me to deliver a live training via WebEx, I am a bit more open to the idea as online training modules do not have to be dry.  However, it does help if individuals want to enroll rather than being forced to do so, but I think the same issue occurs with face-to-face trainings.

Dixie, I love the connection you made regarding the Native American teaching about the two conflicting wolves. I have not heard about this teaching before, but after further research, it is very enlightening! Great post!

I agree with so much of what you said in your post Mark. When you are talking about explicit rules for eLearning, do you think that culture has to be considered when creating those rules? For instance, in this class we have clear rules for discussions as you mention, but do you think our instructor also considers the cultures of the students and how that may affect their communication in discussions when applying grades or when creating class expectations?
Thanks for reading and replying to my post. I recently completed a certification in D&I and bias is one of those topics that relate to subjectivity of the content creator/evaluator.

I look forward to learning more about this. Mark, do you have that experience when you switch between languages and cultures that your biases change? I notice this all the time and it's what makes it gut wrenching for me being in Germany and not wanting to leave and then returning to the States and knowing this is home. I become intolerant of how Germans teach, while I also understand the premises in German teaching that make US teaching of certain subjects seem less valuable. And then stepping back, the amalgamation of all that offers a rich and enriching gumbo...

Mark- Great post about culture being an identity. When reading your post I thought of typical school events such as cultural/world fairs, science fairs, and the like. Obviously these events include projects and work from many different cultures. What method do you think would be best to transfer those as eLearning? I know some of those events involve patrons trying the culture's food, or appreciating the art or trying on a handmade bracelet or other piece of clothing. To me, only in person learning can offer the full experience of these activities. What do you think?

I like the point you bring up. The limitation of the senses in the online setting does not allow a full experience, which also draws on memory - I am reminded of Proust's iconic memory of the madeleine - it's flavor, smell, texture, association. At the same time, I was just talking to a colleague of mine, a dancer who in quarantine participated in a workshop that included outside activities to be done alone as means of grounding and sensing into the material that was being worked on in the eLearning environment. Just connecting with nature according to this colleague cleared the head and body enough and brought in other stimuli to reset her mind to go online. Don't know whether that could be a starting point for something if we are forced to stay online.

Wyatt, I agree there's a power to in-person learning on a topic but videos can be as effective. If I were bringing the activities you mentioned to an eLearning environment I would include videos that will help learners to understand and learn a cultural concept I want them to understand.

Hi Mark, I appreciate the common denominator you've found in culture and e-Learning; I did not even think of that context. Looking at it this way gives one an opportunity to stratify, sort, evaluate, combine, recombine, and keep applying and evaluating what has happened through generations (culture), or can be optimized in the classroom (eLearning).

When I think of culture and eLearning, I think of how to reach cultural communities that may experience difficulties in learning electronically. Some of these groups include rural areas that may not have stable Internet access, groups of people that can’t necessarily afford to purchase high powered technology equipment, and communities that may not be fluent in the language that the learning material is presented in. However, even with the unique hardships that these groups experience, technology can also play a hand in solving them. For example, with the advent of 5G cell service, high speed transmissions are now possible in the most remote of areas and will only continue to grow. What’s more, translation applications have become more and more responsive as of late and gained the ability to translate languages “on the fly”, in some cases right into a wearer’s earbuds. Finally, technology has become so ubiquitous in the past decade that it is becoming reasonably priced for more people than ever to utilize; especially with the development of devices that are designed to pull down data from the cloud such as Chromebooks.
One thing I would like to see in this decade is for technology to become more public, such as kiosks around municipalities that provide information and assistance to an inquirer, sort of like a new style phone booth. These machines would be targeted to individuals who may not carry a smartphone or other mobile computing device. I think a variation of this concept could assist with solving homelessness as well; but that is a discussion for another time.

Hi Wyatt,  Once again, you bring up excellent points regarding some of the limitations in eLearning. One of the challenges our community faces right now (I am sure this is happening up North as well) is lack of network connectivity making it hard for students to attend virtual classes. I know that when the schools closed in March, the bus drivers in our area drove around rural areas to provide free WiFi to communities. I am not sure if that is still something they are doing since I am not working in public schools anymore but it was a great temporary solution. Accessibility is another issue and not just for English Language Learners, but for students who are on IEPs or need assistance. A lot of web conferencing tools, LMS, or eLearning design programs do not have adequate resources to support accessibility and those that do are very minimal such as close captioning. I can give you a great example of this, back in March when I was still teaching, I had to use Zoom to check-in with my students. I had two Deaf students who were receiving interpreting services from a certified ASL interpreter and it was really hard for us to show our students when I was talking and when she was signing. These are some of the things you would expect at this point should be available, but sadly they are not. 
I like your idea of providing free technology for everyone. Providing citizens with access to the Internet and computers would allow them to seek apprenticeships and certifications that are available for free. Sadly, I do not think this will happen anytime soon but I hope to see this in my lifetime.

You know, I've really been thinking about eLearning from a current events place, bemoaning having to do everything on Zoom, but thinking about rural communities who may be glad for the the switch to more online platforms has certainly reminded me that this situation offers possibility, not just "inconvenience." Thanks for that!

I think that's a great idea too! I don't live in a rural area, but I've heard of stories of students who have to wake up at 4 AM for the bus to pick them up at 6 AM because they are an hour away from the nearest school. I can imagine this might be a relief for some of these students and their families, but then the connectivity issue can be a real problem that creates a new problem instead of a solution.

Wow, Wyatt!  Imagine the implications.  I grew up in a small rural town.  Our class read the school's student handbook, which stated that if at least ten students wanted a course that fell within the curriculum guidelines, the school would offer it.  For our foreign language course, we wanted either French or German (a million years ago, so I do not remember which exactly except we debated between these two before going to the principal with our decision).  We wound up only being offered Spanish, the only other language with an existing teacher.  We also never truly had a choice in any other electiives - no art, music, etc.  Also, underprivileged urban areas probably go through something similar.  I think your vision for public technology access is a solution to leveling a very uneven playing field. BTW, I used Google translate when I went to CDMX in January.  I would love the Star Trek-type translators you mentiond

Hi Wayatt, I'm glad you brought up that point about eLearning in rural areas with poor internet service. I recently drove through southeast New Mexico and was wondering myself how people can work on the Internet in such rural areas? All I could think of is some kind of satellite dish a person could install on their home, I did not know 5G was so versatile!

I would define culture as the beliefs, customs, habits or standard practices of a group of people. I always have a hard time putting that definition into words, but I believe it is all of those things and then some that people tend to be accustomed to based on their family, community and environment. 
I would define eLearning as a mode of education that takes place through the use of technology instead of relying mainly on face to face interaction with an instructor or others. 
Culture and eLearning are related because culture affects learning in any capacity that it takes place. Our culture affects our attitude towards learning, towards the subjects we learn and the way in which we learn, so it is important to take all of these things into account when designing an eLearning experience for students.

Hi Stephanie, I like the causality you present in the two terms. I also am immediately reminded of how biases and stereotypes can influence what you posit in a negative way so that taking the time to contemplate this relationship also opens the arena to identifying, addressing, and perhaps changing these biases.

Hi Stephanie, I agree with your definitions and they are concise and easy to remember! You make an excellent point regarding the connection between culture and eLearning and its impact on learning. Our cultural beliefs dictate how we learn as well as how we respond to certain ideas which in turn makes it important to think about the audience and what is going to prevent them from taking away what was presented in your eLearning course. As I started reading for this course, and some of the content in the module, this was something we really need to think about. I am glad to see that we are starting to think about how our cultural beliefs shape the way we create our instruction and what we can do to minimize that.

Stephanie, I agree, culture is definitely a belief or an arbitrary concept of social norms. It is easier to give examples of culture rather than a one statement definition for sure. I like how you mentioned that culture is what people are accustomed to within their community. That is exactly what I think of culture. Things that are understood or happen often as a normal routine. eLearning seemed easy to define, at least easier than culture. Distant learning is eLearning, but it can encompass face-to-face learning too. My children started second and seventh grade and they are learning face to face, online, at least two days per week. Laura
I would agree with that definition of culture.  It is hard for me to define as well.

In Germany, one frequently adds "art" when talking about culture, Kunst und Kultur, are like twins joined at the hip - in the Western Christian paradigm, I think art development created a culture and with secularization, the parameters of culture transcended the parameters of religion and its seeming by-products art and culture. I see culture as an amalgam of adopted values, language, rituals, and an inherent pride.
eLearning is a tool that enables the creation of an education setting even in places not conducive to learning. eLearning can serve individuals who might otherwise feel outed, vulnerable, or inferior. 
eLearning can offer a forum in which one can be as cultural or a-cultural as one wants to be in conveying content. Since culture is also a part of racial, social, and caste settings, I would posit it represents an opportunity to think about a learning environment that can address racial and social injustice  and delimit caste in a safe zone and place of exploration.
PS: I was just reminded of Margaret Mead's identification of culture not so much being the anthropological artifacts she found but the discovery of a femur that had broken and mended indicating that the individual in question had been cared for and not left to their own devices. That idea permeates the domain of eLearning nicely in the context of creating a circle of care of the intellect or fostering abilities - perhaps demonstrating a vision for what wisdom can do.

Hi Eva, the part you included about "inherent pride" in your definition truly caught my attention. It made me reflect on my idea of pride and where it comes from and I was able to link it back to different sources such as my parents, religious beliefs, and even books. 
You make an excellent point that eLearning can provide opportunities for people that do not have access to education to have one. However, the issue is that many minority groups do not have access to eLearning because they do not have the tools to participate such as a computer and Internet. Wyatt makes an excellent point in his post that this can be a reality if everyone had access to technology by setting up kiosks or even giving people free computers and Internet access. In doing so, we would be able to expand eLearning for everyone and provide more learning opportunities for everyone from people with disabilities to senior citizens.

Hi Melissa,Thanks for further qualifying the access issue! I was thinking within a narrow scope of people who simply don't want to or psychologically find it too harrowing to interact in live settings. I helped develop a platform for online writing classes that were supposed to supplement the Taos Summer Writers' Conference summer live session and our WordPress platform designer was telling me that would be the ideal spot for him to learn in his PJs because he just couldn't deal with people and didn't want anyone to look at him. That gave me some insights. I've also worked with a number of people on the autism spectrum through my bodywork over the years and they have loved the solitude of online learning.

Eva, thank you for sharing this concept with us. I enjoy learning new things and this is one concept I will remember: Kunst und Kultur. 
It's very interesting to think that one can decide to be whomever one wants to be in an eLearning environment.
In my view, eLearning tends to be very cold and dry, devoid of character, in format. Oftentimes the goal is to target a universal learner. In reflecting on my eLearning experience, many of the modules I have been required to complete are targeted content for its given audience. 
If the practice remains true, most of us who have to complete required compliance training go directly to the exam and test out of the module. 
I feel for the person who spent 100s of hours working on the content.
Eva, I was thinking about the use of the word culture in terms of this attainable but lofty (and socio-economically motivated) goal and how it came to be such a narrow expression as well!
Yes! Hope we'll have more opportunity to discuss. I'd be interested how culture influences your writing especially in diverse genres it must reveal itself differently?

I have written characters from different cultures and different time periods and I have to say, the most helpful thing (besides research, obviously) to writing them with cultural sensitivity, is to really learn to detach from my own ego (to go a little Buddhist on you!). Like, if you can just start out a blank slate and just absorb another culture without any thoughts of what it says about your own culture, it feels more genuine. At least, that's what I hope has happened, haha!

Interesting, Michelle - that's actually the foundation for the Core Synchronism work I do (it's similar to craniosacral), I can only scan and work with cerebrospinal fluid on mental/emotional/physical planes when I disengage and just ask that person's Core to guide me to places of friction.
I know in the writing I've done, it's going into the five senses, which pulls you out of your cerebral space - and I've learned a lot of that doing homeopathic intakes, because it's in the five senses that you are able to get to the client's actual state, rather than letting them rationalize and you go into conjecture rather than presenting symptoms..
I look forward to reading something of yours - famous last words looking at the stack of to be read books on various tables throughout the house...

Hello, Eva.  I like your view on how eLearning can create a safe space.  I have been in classes where one or two people dominate the [physical] classroom and pretty much, no one else will speak up because they will feel they will be bullied if they do.  However, I have noticed the same type of individuals in online courses, and even though they still strongly state their view points in the discussion forum, because 1) we are governed by strict netiquette rules, and 2) people can ignore these individuals if they choose, 3) substantial written participation is required in discussions, I feel that everyone truly has a chance to have themselves heard -kind of what Mark was stating regarding eLearning rules.  I have gotten to "hear" a lot of different view points I would have otherwise never had a chance to be spoken had those discussions been held face-to-face.

Thanks, Michelle! When you lay it out like that I have to think about the different goals in COI vs WisCom - former being more self-reflexive but still serving the community, while latter is prefaced on contributions being made to build the community. And in both cases, the rules, as you pointed out Mark had established, are necessary - which I suppose ties into authentic learning, because everyone is eager to stick to rules in order to solve a problem. Look forward to continuing the discussion.

In an education class I took there was a reading where the author had an interesting metaphor about culture. They said that it was like the air you breathe or the water around a fish.  It was saying that it is so ubiquitous that everything you do is affected by it, and if to natives of that culture it can be invisible to them. Other than that culture is pretty much everything: language, food, religion, art, music, symbols, priorities, gestures, economy, etc...
I think eLearning is a way to teach someone a class or a skill digitally.  I think it also includes a management system that collects work, tracks, sends correspondence, and/or certifies the person who completed the class. This is how it would differentiate from just traditional educational media, which can also be digital.
Megan, I agree with your statement that to a native, culture is generally invisible.  I have found that travel and exposing myself to other cultures is a good way to "open my eyes" to my own culture.

Dixie, I like how you took Meagan's apt definition and then reflected it back - while othering can be negative in some contexts, I think taking the time to look at other cultures and then think about one's own can lead to an internal/external dialog that has so many positive and constructive touch points.
Yeah, I agree, being able to travel is a great thing!

Electronic learning is the process of acquiring information or skills through modern technology. While what first comes to mind is the notion of a student in front of a computer watching a teacher in another part of town, another part of the country, or another part of the world explain and instruct a topic, as I examine this image, I immediately realize how it's only one facet of e-learning. 
In today's culture, we are all e-learners and many of us have powerful computers in our pockets, able to teach us something at a moment's notice. YouTube is a prime example of this. Gone, in large part, are the days of buying a manual for how to repair your car. With a few good search words, you can find numerous videos showing you how to change a tire, replace a headlight, and even much more complex techniques. Ebook sales are outstripping traditionally printed books and there are many websites where you can simply read a book online instead of downloading it for use in a device like Kindle. Seasame Street has taught young children the alphabet, numbers, and how to be kind for more than 50 years. Netflix is filled with documentaries about astrophysics, cooking, alien abductions, and how to de-clutter your home. The Duolingo app on my phone quizzes me on Spanish words. Skillshare is an online subscription service offering thousands of pre-recorded classes.
We have more access to learning than any other culture in our planet's history. It's so common that it has become second nature and when we use the word "e-learning," most people revert to my original image: that of a formal, live, online class.
Two concepts of culture come to mind when I try to write a definition for this word. The first is a reference to a person's social heritage: the stories and traditions that develop among a group of people. This may be as broad as the history of an ethnicity or tribe or race, or as specific as the recounting of a family's experiences or the mores of a corporation. Culture in this definition is often expressed through how a person dresses, the food they eat, the music they listen to, the way they dance. But it is also, I believe, deeply rooted in their personal identity. For example, I am an American, but if I travel or even move to Arizona, I would say I'm New Mexican because that is how I feel inside, even though I might know Phoenix like the back of my hand (is that even possible?) and cheer for the Cardinals. My native Phoenician neighbor and I might both be American, but she's an Arizonan and I'm a New Mexican.
It occurs to me that we use the word culture to also identify those traits that make someone somehow loftier in terms of education and access to things like art and music. The image that comes to mind (perhaps it's from a movie?) is of well-dressed people attending the opera or an art exhibit opening, sipping champagne and acting very "cultured." I think this context also applies to "cultured pearls," so in these examples, culture means polished or rarefied. In my movie, the people are generally white and it makes me wonder if "culture" as a polish takes the place of the deeper culture of family history and societal connections that perhaps were lost.

Hi Michelle,
I really like how you defined culture based on your personal experiences. I agree that when I think of culture I automatically think of food, language, religion, dress, and ethnicity. This is the generic definition used in textbooks that you find in elementary schools and one of the NM social studies standards for teaching focuses on teaching students that culture is all about language, customs, and religion. 
I was also interested in your definition of culture in terms of status and from a critical perspective. Now that I think about it, we do use the word culture as a sign of power and high status. This is definitely something to consider as we continue discussing what the word "culture" means.

I know I went a bit off on a tangent with the other definition/use of culture (that's my English geek side coming out) but I figure, anything that makes us more aware of any unrealized biases can only help us learn to be better educators

Rahim AlHaj, an oud player from Iran in an interview was saying the only two states he could imagine having moved to in the US when he had to leave his home country were Louisiana and New Mexico, and he elaborated that a distinct cuisine and rich cultural offerings/arts were prerequisite to him to identify something as having culture.
I realy like how you mentioned culture being a reference to someone's social heritage. I feel like this is really important because it definitely influences who we become as a person

Tanya, I also believe that eLearning involves a formal, on-line class.  And, in my post, I described this semester as my first experience with eLearning.  But, upon reflection, that really isn't true.  This is my first formal, on-line class.  But, I have used computers and other electronic technology in learning and training many times before.  A simulator could be considered eLearning, I suppose.

Michelle, Great post! I agree with your comments about your first thoughts when it comes to Electronic Learning. Great insights about YouTube and educational shows! This is something that I think is easily looked over. I agree that we have so many opportunities that we don't even realize right at our fingertips.

I would define culture as the culmination of all dominant and non-dominant aspects of society that influence institutions (on a societal level) and individuals (on a psychological level).  However, I do not think how cultures affect societies and individuals are a one-way street.  For example, religions are part of culture, but other institutions, such as governments and economics, can influence them.  The same with people, which is how sub-cultures can form.  

I think eLearning as many people think of it, is a medium by which learning is delivered.  For example, I am old enough to remember telecourses, where we had to watch community college lectures on local cable channels or watch VHS tapes (wow, I'm old).  However, I think with interactive technologies nowadays, it can be so much more.  I have sat through some horrible online courses, where they are essentially the same dry lectures with no real interaction, and I have been throughly engaged in dynamic courses with lively class discussions and workshops.  I think that much like an in-class experience, eLearning can be more than a medium to deliver the traditional banking model of education remotely.

Hi Michelle, 

Both you and Michelle M. made interesting points about seeing culture from a critical perspective. I agree that dominant cultures influence all aspects of life from religion, education, government, and other ideologies. For example, there is a notion that the United States was built on Christian principles that have influenced how our government works and even our work ethic. This is definitely something to consider as we start thinking about putting our cultural beliefs aside when we develop instruction to make it equitable for everyone. 

I like your concluding statement regarding eLearning; I agree that we have to move away from that banking model of education which is what is starting to happen as teachers are moving to eLearning. eLearning, in my opinion, can be the key to transforming our broken education system, but I am concerned that we are continuing to stick to our old ways of teaching which is going to cause further problems in terms of equity and accessibility. I feel like it is important that we start putting aside our cultural beliefs and be open to changes and new ways of teaching.

Hello, Melissa.  Although hesitant 15 years ago, I am very excited about the possibility eLearning brings.  Especially after reading some of the posts from our peers, it may be a greatest factor in creating equal opportunity.

Hey, you're not old just because you can remember using VHS! (I can too!). And I agree about how an online course can be just as dry and unrewarding as an inperson course, but the potential for a dynamic learning environment still exists, we just need to figure out how to break though that screen barrier!

Hello, Michelle.  Screen barrier - love it (the term, not the obtacle, lol)!  I have had some instructors break through it.  However, they also seem the type that would have also made an in-person class interesting.  As Mark brought up, I think eLearning has gotten a bad wrap because it was not used correctly in the beginning.  I think awesome instructors + new technology will help shatter the barrier.  Let's do this!

Tanya, love your hodgepodge culture definition and I so agree! Moving back and forth between Germany and the US, I've felt lacking in true cultural identity but in fact, it's the sum of the various bits I've been exposed to that creates another layer I am seeing reflected in my children with whom I discuss culture and identity a lot. Now that my daughter is studying in Hawaii, she is looking at another layer of culture she thought she had understood living in NM, going to public school, engaging with a diverse cohort, but it presents altogether differently in island indigenous culture. Really fascinating. Thank you.

Eva, I grew up exclusively in the US and I still felt a lack of cultural identity until probably after college when I studied my mom's genealogy and learned about our Mexican heritage. I identified so strongly with that side of me...until I took one of those DNA ancestry tests and discovered that while my grandmother's family lived for generations in Mexico, they were Spanish/Europeans who really didn't assimilate/intermarry much. I instantly felt adrift, which I know is silly, but the European/American side of me felt somehow lacking in what I see as cultural identity.

Interesting, so is there also something self-reflexive in a quest for cultural identity because we want to belong? In the post-WWII German generation I find it interesting how many young people in distancing themselves from German/Nazi/Third Reich history and trying to attempt an anti-nationalist stance, in fact turned to looking for sects to join, leaving Germany to pursue esoteric studies - Germans literally show up everywhere there's a New Age movement. Just throwing that out there.

I appreciate that sense of feeling "adrift" because it speaks to the ability to be vulnerable, the space in which we actually make connections.

I'm glad you liked my hodgepodge culture definition. I wasn't quite sure how to explain it. I really like your description of layers of culture and how that applies in your life. That make so much sense and gives me a new way to describe experience.

When I think of the term culture what comes to mind is a group of people’s beliefs, values, norms, knowledge and customs. The term culture is not one that is easy to define because it encompasses many things. When I think of the term eLearning I think of online learning and learning that takes place through the use of technology and does not occur in a face to face situation. Culture and eLearning are related because one’s learning is influenced by their beliefs, values, customs, community, and their overall environment. One learns by drawing connections with what they know and have experienced.

I agree that there's not a clear cut definition of culture as I view it as an array of different things. It's like the umbrella of all the things you mentioned: beliefs, values, norms, knowledge, and customs. I completely agree that the way we construct our knowledge is based on our cultural beliefs and that is going to influence how we teach as well.
You made a good point about how it will influence how we teach as well, this is something I forgot to include in my original post. I will definitely have to include it in my definition of culture.

would describe culture as the underlying abstract forces and motivations in a group that help to inform and guide the beliefs, values, atmosphere, and life choices of the people immersed within it. It manifests in all areas of a persons life including how one defines and maneuvers through life and interactions with others. Different influential people and situations can cause culture to shift or evolve. Sometimes the evolution is a result of conflicting aspects of the current culture which can diverge into new groups. Culture then influences the concrete artifacts of life such as language, music, arts etc. which are things that continue to reinforce the feelings of understanding and belonging of those in the group.
When I think of eLearning I feel like it’s a process of figuring out how to build relationships and understanding without the physical and continual proximity we normally have with others we are forming relationships with. So we have to rely on other formats of communicating and exchanging ideas and information to do so. The reinforcing aspects of human physical contact and sharing plays a huge role in the building of culture and belonging so those aspects have to be captured and maintained in other ways in order for it to be successful.
In thinking about how the two concepts relate, I feel that it is about understanding the commonalities, goals and motivations of those in the group. Both also require a recognition and willingness to do the work that is necessary to build understanding and the feeling of belonging and growth within the group in order to meet individual and group needs.

I love your take on what eLearning means! We are taking the standard definition and adding the lack of physical and continual proximity that comes with this type of learning with an emphasis on utilizing other forms of communication. I agree with your response regarding the relationship between culture and eLearning and I can see how goals, motivation, and commonalities will lead to successful eLearning as well as frequent collaboration and empathizing with everyone who is a part of the eLearning process. 

You also mentioned that successful culture-building focuses on building physical relationships, but I would like to add that you can build a culture online as you can create a relationship with people through online communication. Thanks to social media, text messaging, video games, and other online platforms people are building new cultures as they are connecting with different people and creating relationships that don't require any physical contact or proximity.

I agree that you can and I am learning the nuances of what that can look like. I have spent my life working with others on reading and interacting with tiny humans to help build some of the skills we need to be successful as adults navigating a social world...this is a whole new context for me and I am excited to learn more about this side of culture-building!

I agree that you can and I am learning the nuances of what that can look like. I have spent my life working with others on reading and interacting with tiny humans to help build some of the skills we need to be successful as adults navigating a social world...this is a whole new context for me and I am excited to learn more about this side of culture-building!

I really identify with your comment about eLearning needing to figure out the in-person cues and communications that make a (good) in-person class dynamic. I'm realizing I have some preconceived notions about eLearning!

I completely relate Michelle! As an early childhood professional who manages, coaches, and mentors teachers I am so used to the face to face with children and adults...reading body language, cues, building communication skills etc. I have so much to learn about eLearning. We did remote learning with preschoolers and toddlers while we were closed and it was amazing to see their engagement....

Culture to me includes a vast array of influences on a person which develops how they view themselves as well as how others view them. These influences include beliefs, norms, language, religion, nationality, color, education level, the community in they were raised, traditions, music, food, and many more. People’s cultures will only become more dynamic as more people from different backgrounds continue to bring their cultures together and pass them down to their offspring.

ELearning is the process by which individuals learn through a variety of electronic mediums to include video, audio, text. It does not always need to be at a distance, however, it is becoming more popular and efficient for teaching and learning to be conducted over the internet.

Culture is related to eLearning as it is a major component to consider when developing online content that will be utilized by a variety of people from different backgrounds. An example of a cultural consideration in developing online content is that of whether the anticipated audience is generally from a high context or low context culture. If they are from a low context culture, such as western countries, they may be used to all information needed to understand the subject material to be explained in writing. Where in a high context culture, like many Asian countries, the audience may be more familiar with learning material that comes with contexts such as tone and body gestures.

I think you accurately summarized the relationship between culture and eLearning. Ultimately, we have to consider who we are creating content for and how their culture affects their learning. I appreciate you bringing up high and low context cultures because this is not something we consider when we are developing content. Instructors usually design according to what they think is best, without taking into account their audience. That is why getting to know our audience is important that way we can go back and modify our content to make it accessible to everyone. Thank you for your insight!
What Melissa said! My thoughts exactly.

Like Melissa, I appreciate this high/low context consideration you bring up. This is new terminology for me but it addresses exactly aspects of culture I have struggled with moving between continents and countries. It also is a helpful way of what I have found so challenging in the translation work (especially literary translation and art related texts) over the last three and a half decades because aside from cultural connotations that complexity of going from high to low and vice-versa is really challenging without adding pages of explanatory footnotes. Thank you for bringing this up!

Like Melissa, I appreciate this high/low context consideration you bring up. This is new terminology for me but it addresses exactly aspects of culture I have struggled with moving between continents and countries. It also is a helpful way of what I have found so challenging in the translation work (especially literary translation and art related texts) over the last three and a half decades because aside from cultural connotations that complexity of going from high to low and vice-versa is really challenging without adding pages of explanatory footnotes. Thank you for bringing this up!

I believe that eLearning happens throughout the day, most days. There are many different forums and sites that individuals can access and learn from, without even trying to learn. In an academic setting, this is an eLearning course. There are many apps and forms of social media that are not intended to "teach", but end up doing so. There are easily accessible tutorials on Facebook, Youtube, Pinterest, etc., which is so neat. These are often easy to access and do not cost money, which is even better because that means there is more potential for a wider audience to be reached. We are accessing the course lectures and assignments all through electronics. I prefer in-person learning, I like sitting in a classroom and seeing my professor and classmates, but at this time that is not possible. 

Similarly to eLearning, culture can have multiple meanings and can be expressed differently. To me culture is influenced by my upbringing and family/social norms. Some things that seem normal to me, may be foreign to others. I think it is important to learn about other cultures and be accepting even if something is different than the way I do something.

Alexis, I'm trying to read Teaching Crowds parallel to class work and reading and it's exactly that principle of myriad learning opportunities that don't even feel like learning which also define what eLearning can be. Seems like so much potential to reframe the model and make it enriching, especially by looking at learning in problem-based/problem-solving contexts so there are tangible outcomes. 

I noticed my greatest concern with these many online opportunities is also the inherent danger of capitalist manipulation/brainwashing through advertising, which is driven by a profit-oriented model, and associated biases being reinforced. While in-person learning can do all of that as well based on the materials used, there seems to be more control as well as space to convey the importance of critical thinking. I'm struggling with this issue.

I liked when you brought up eLearning throughout the day. Earlier this week, after writing a post about my experiences with eLearning, I realised that there were probably a dozen instances I had not thought of at the time I had written it. Learning online has already become ubiquitous before COVID, it became more obvious after.

I'm sorry, I confused this with the journal posting! But here's my answer:


From what I understand from prior studies and experience, I believe culture can be defined as the conglomerate of people/experiences/places/heritage that contributes to a person's creation of self. It includes the influences of such things as family, community, language, socioeconomic status, race, gender, and society. One of the most fascinating aspects of culture for me is the dichotomy between individualistic and collectivistic cultures.

My definition of eLearning begins first with the understanding of learning. For me, I see learning as a process whereby one takes in information, makes connections to that new information, and then shapes it into meaning based on prior knowledge and personal interpretation. Elearning, whether formal or informal,  then layers on the use of electronic materials to span distance divides between teacher and student, such as internet, various online platforms, streaming, and hardware such as laptops/chromebooks.

I think I am in the same boat as you were this week. I like your description of culture.

Heritage and experiences definitely reflect how culture is perceived within a community. Also, the people, who make culture, is a great way to see how culture is understood. I look at the Untied States and we have so many community cultures within American culture. For example, different religions, ethnicity, and hobbies around the country help shape those cultural norms.

I think I am in the same boat as you were this week. I like your description of culture.

Heritage and experiences definitely reflect how culture is perceived within a community. Also, the people, who make culture, is a great way to see how culture is understood. I look at the Untied States and we have so many community cultures within American culture. For example, different religions, ethnicity, and hobbies around the country help shape those cultural norms.
Rebecca I did exactly the same thing!

Culture seems like it has a broad meaning. One that could be defined differently when examined within different cultures around the world. For example, I think culture in America is based around our Constitutional freedoms. Many Americans take pride in having the opportunity do make choices about their daily life, especially within their family. Others feel much differently because of the availability of resources within lower SES communities. Either way, there is a place to belong in a community where culture is rich in description.

eLearning seems to me more commonly defined, in my opinion. Almost everyone learning anything right now is doing it electronically. eLearning can be performed in various ways, such as lectures, discussions forums and self-guided reading.

Hi Laura, I'm so glad I'm not alone! I got confused with the journal assignment too and just followed the embedded instructions before I saw the instructions about wisdom when I was doing my double check that I got all the stuff done for the week today! Yeeks! Hopefully, it goes smoother from here on in.

I like how you point out that the definition of culture can be variable depending on the culture from which perspective it is being viewed. A bit meta, but definitely true! It is interesting how relevant eLearning is to everyone right now with CoVid 19 influencing our learning environments so much!

Thank you for your post, Becky

Culture seems like it has a broad meaning. One that could be defined differently when examined within different cultures around the world. For example, I think culture in America is based around our Constitutional freedoms. Many Americans take pride in having the opportunity do make choices about their daily life, especially within their family. Others feel much differently because of the availability of resources within lower SES communities. Either way, there is a place to belong in a community where culture is rich in description.

eLearning seems to me more commonly defined, in my opinion. Almost everyone learning anything right now is doing it electronically. eLearning can be performed in various ways, such as lectures, discussions forums and self-guided reading.

I would define culture as the set of values and beliefs that a person uses as a framework for viewing and interacting with the world.  I think a lot of times it tends to get confused with geographic origin, race, ethnicity, spirituality, employment background, age or a number of other areas.  I think all of those things can contribute to a persons culture, but no one of them is the totality of their culture.  For example, I have heard people refer to the "culture" of where I grew up (Indiana) or where I live (New Mexico), but I really do not understand what that means when they say that:  There is a lot of diversity in both of those areas.  Indiana is where I grew up, but it doesn't define who I am.  

eLearning is something that is very new to me.  I would have to describe most of my experience with eLearning as really more of "eTesting" or "eDocumenting":  Where I work, it is used almost exclusively for compliance documentation. It is almost always an on-line power point presentation, followed by a multiple choice test.  I would describe actual eLearning as a non-traditional form of instruction that utilizes technology to overcome barriers of geography and time to allow greater access to education.  But, I may be way off base there.  As I said, this is my first real experience with it.  This class and the other one that I am taking on-line are very new and different to me.  

I think that culture and eLearning are related to each other in that effective eLearning must take into account a very wide range of cultures.  It is likely the widest range in existence.  When students have the potential to come from all stations of life and all corners of the world, that tends to negate a traditional model of education where students often share geographic location, age, employment background or other cultural influences.  I will be interested to see how the WisCom model addresses that:  It seems like a daunting task.

Your take on what eLearning should be able to do is compelling and the age factor only just stuck out for me. I don't know how facile most of you in the group are working with eBooks, but that has proven my biggest challenge over the last years in which I've taken online classes or even when I was taking an American Studies grad class a few years back and wanted to be more environmentally conscious about paper use, so I tried to work with some of our books in a kindle version. I feel disoriented and am trying to come up with solutions just to feel knowledge I am used to highlighting, transferring to index cards or notebooks, copying etc. slips away in electronic form,  even with highlighting and note taking options - I imagine for a number of adult learners transitioning into eLearning this is something that could be addressed in some way - I don't know whether the authentic learning model could do that?

It's interesting to see your thoughts on eBooks.  This is an issue that I have been struggling with as well, but I thought I was just not as tech-savy as other people.  I find it harder to go back to a specific item in an ebook, it is much easier to do with a paper book.  I have noticed that the supplier of the ebook makes a difference.  Some sites allow you to mark pages and highlight areas.  Some allow you to copy and paste the text to another document.  Some sites are more restrictive about these things.  By the time I am finished with my degree, I may figure this out!

Thank you, Dixie! I actually gave up on a sports nutrition program because of the inadequate resources. I would love to stay in touch and compare notes! I think it could be a valuable tutorial/community input/let's optimize this together kind of moment.

Eva and Dixie--
I don't think the difficulty of eBooks is an age thing at all! There is lots of research about the brain/paper connection and retention. I simply have to have a hard copy of a book if I'm using it for research/learning, although I do enjoy my Kindle for my pleasure reading (that being said, I still remember books better if I've held the paper version in my hand). I don't know what the answer is for a trend toward eBooks.

Thanks, Michelle! I wind  up buying hard copies of everything and feeling guilty about the paper, though non-fiction science writer Priscilla Long at some point wrote that the cost of electronics was much higher than one imagined and paper, was, in fact, not as wasteful as one thought...

I too personally prefer to have a hard copy of the book I am reading. I have especially found this to be true for my textbooks for the OILS program. I like the hard copy of the book because as I'm reading I like to highlight and make notes to help me learn and remember what I am reading as well as make connections with it. I also go in and print all of the electronic articles that our professors post that way I can mark the text as I read them. I feel like when I can't do this I really struggle with making connections and remembering what I read. Students now days aren't being taught the same way the majority of us were growing up with highlighting, making index cards etc, so it has been interesting changing the way I teach to fit them and make it more technologically friendly and engaging. It is amazing to see how far we have come technologically since I was in high school just 13 years ago.

Hello, all.  I wound up loving it once books came out on Kindle because as I had many science and math classes where the books were heavy and unwieldy.  I have a garage full of books I could not sell back that I am having a hard time throwing away because they are books.  That being said, some platforms are better than others.  I generally like the Kindle platform because it allows for highlighting and including your own notes.  I was never able to study/write using index cards, but I did see a flashcards option on the app.  I found the B&N app to be useless a few years ago when I tried it, but they may have improved it since then.  Now that our books are available for the OILS courses though the library, I will be playing with various note taking apps to see how to capture/mark up the pages.  I am open to suggestions if anyone has had success with particular apps.  With so many people replying to this particular issue, it seems like a good item to have as a dedicated and ongoing discussion thread.  Is anyone interested?

I can completely relate to having heavy and unwieldy textbooks that couldn't be sold back and having a hard time throwing them away. I feel like throwing them away is like throwing away the $60+ i paid for them even though they served their purpose. I have found that I enjoy reading books on my kindle for my fun, but when it comes to school and work textbooks, I definitely prefer the hard copy to refer back to as needed. I love your idea of experimenting with different apps for marking the text. I haven't come across any that I really like, but I am definitely interested in taking part in the ongoing discussion thread about different ones. That is a great idea!

Thank you for that, Faith! I may just revert to my hard copy system as well though I do keep trying to keep kindle notes etc. Certainly as we develop our own materials for use, it's something that needs to be tackled in a 21st century way.

I would have to say that culture is what makes every person unique. It is based on customs, knowledge, belief systems and norms. I think it is something learned and can be observed by others. It is what makes a person or even groups of people unique.

eLearning is just a way to describe a type of learning. There is traditional or classroom learning. There is this type because for one reason or another we can't make it onto campus to sit in a classroom.

I can see eLearning or eLearners as their own group or culture since we fall into a different "cultural" category than the normal student. I think the idea of being an eLearner with my own unique set of customs is neat.

I agree with you about culture being what makes every person unique. I love meeting people and talking to them about their cultures because I find it really interesting and love to learn new things. It's amazing how much we can truly learn about one another and from one another just by listening.
Great post! I had a hard time connecting these two words, but I think you did a great job!

I've enjoyed reading and replying to most of your responses. It seems like we have similar responses in terms of defining culture and eLearning. I think now we have to come to a consensus on a definition and how they are related? 

Based on what I interpreted from reading everyone's responses, culture is someone's beliefs about the world around them which encompasses many different things like language, norms, traditions, and personal knowledge. eLearning, on the other hand, is a type of learning that is done outside of a traditional classroom and relies on technology such as the a computer and Internet access. 

Culture and eLearning are related because it's a type of culture that has different norms and most importantly, we have to consider the vast cultural groups being represented in the classroom as we develop content. 

Please feel free to disagree or add! :)
Great synthesis, Melissa. Thank you.

Hi Melissa, I would say you did a great job summarizing everyone's thoughts on culture and eLearning. One thing I feel is important for eLearning that we should include is that it is delivered through the use of the internet.

Thank you for your responses! So to add to our definition we should say: 


Culture is someone's beliefs about the world around them which encompasses many different things like language, norms, traditions, and personal knowledge. eLearning, on the other hand, is a type of learning that is done outside of a traditional classroom through the use of the Internet. 

Culture and eLearning are related because it's a type of culture that has different norms and most importantly, we have to consider the vast cultural groups being represented in the classroom as we develop content.
